prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: MACS0257 [CII] 158um
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: To map [CII] 158 um line as well as Band 7 continuum with a 0.2" resolution.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Note: The requested observing parameters are summarized in Table 1 in the Scientific Justification.
---------------- Target features ----------------
[CII] 158 um line and dust continuum. At z=4.69, the [CII] line is redshifted into Band 7.
--------- Pointing ---------
Based on the SMA image in Figure 3, we expect to detect four lensed images. The diagonal image separation (A--D, B--C) is ~17'', which is comparable to the primary beam size in Band 7. Therefore, to avoid placing all four components near the edge of the primary beam, which would cause a significant loss of sensitivity, we will image the two brightest components A and B only by pointing ALMA to the mid-point between the two. This will produce two independent measurements of the background SMG, which will help us improve the accuracy of the lens model and assess the reality of faint features. In terms of the final sensitivity, coadding the two brightest images obtained this way (each displaced by 5'' from the field center) is comparable to observing Component A (or B) alone by placing it at the field center. Therefore, we use the latter case for the sensitivity calculation for simplicity.
------------------- Spatial resolution -------------------
The SMA map shows that Components A and B are compact and barely resolved with a beam of 0.79''x0.7''. To examine the spatial and velocity structures of these sources in greater detail, we request a spatial resolution of 0.2".
----------------- Correlator setup -----------------
For a good sampling of the line profile, we will use the correlator mode with dual polarization, 1.875 GHz bandwidth, and 7.813 MHz (7 km/s) resolution, and will average to 20 km/s channels.
------------ Sensitivity ------------
The total [CII] line flux (~100 Jy km/s) was estimated by assuming a L_[CII]/L_{TIR} ratio of 10^{-3 }. The total line flux was then scaled to the Component A contribution by distributing the flux in proportional to the SMA-measured continuum flux densities ($\sim$40\% $\rightarrow$ 40 Jy km/s).
The SMA map has a beam of 0.79"x0.7", and the source is barely resolved. Therefore, we derived the line flux per ALMA beam by scaling with the ratio of the ALMA and SMA beam sizes, (0.2"x0.2")/(0.79"x0.7").
The integrated CO lines are broad (~700-1100 km/s FWHM; Figure 2), but the velocity width within an ALMA beam without a system-wide gradient is likely ~100 km/s. Therefore, we divide the ALMA-beam line flux by this velocity width. The resultant peak flux density per ALMA beam is 29 mJy.
Since the line is bright, we aim to achieve a high signal-to-noise ratio of 20. The requested sensitivity is therefore 1.5 mJy. The required observing time is 0.61 hours.
The continuum brightness of Component A is 20 mJy at 880 um. By scaling with the ratio of the ALMA and SMA beam sizes (0.2"x0.2")/(0.79"x0.7"), the expected continuum flux per ALMA beam is 1.4 mJy. Since the expected continuum sensitivity is 0.09 mJy according to the ALMA OT, the continuum will be detected with a signal to noise of 16 per ALMA beam, which should be high enough to resolve star-forming clumps in the source.

----------------- Correlator setup -----------------
For a good sampling of the line profile, we will use the correlator mode with dual polarization, 1.875 GHz bandwidth, and 7.813 MHz (7 km/s) resolution, and will average to 20 km/s channels.
The integrated CO lines are broad (~700-1100 km/s FWHM; Figure 2), but the velocity width within an ALMA beam without a system-wide gradient is likely ~100 km/s. The 20km/s channels will allow us to critically sample the line profile with 5 spectral resolution elements per line width.

------------------- Spatial resolution -------------------
The SMA map shows that Components A and B are compact and barely resolved with a beam of 0.79''x0.7''. To examine the spatial and velocity structures of these sources in greater detail, we request a spatial resolution of 0.2". Also, none of the features we see in the SMA map is larger than 2".

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: MACS0257 CO(5-4)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: To map the CO(5-4) line and Band 3 continuum with a 0.5" resolution.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Note: The requested observing parameters are summarized in Table 1 in the Scientific Justification.
---------------- Target features ----------------
CO(5-4) line and dust continuum.
At z=4.69, the CO(5-4) line is redshifted into Band 3.
--------- Pointing ---------
Based on the SMA image in Figure 3, we expect to detect four lensed images. The diagonal image separation (A--D, B--C) is ~17'' In Band 3, the primary beam is large enough to observe the four components in one shot by pointing to the center of the four. We use Component A to guide our sensitivity calculation for simplicity.
------------------- Spatial resolution -------------------
The SMA map shows that Components A and B are compact and barely resolved with a beam of 0.79''x0.7''. To examine the spatial and velocity structures of these sources in greater detail and to better compare with the 0.2" images obtained for the Band 7 and 6 observations, we request the best Band 6 spatial resolution of 0.5".
----------------- Correlator setup -----------------
For a good sampling of the line profile, we will use the correlator mode with dual polarization, 1.875 GHz bandwidth, and 1.938 MHz (6 km/s) resolution, and will average to 20 km/s channels.
------------ Sensitivity ------------
The total CO(5-4) line flux (8.2 Jy km/s) is from our own measurement using IRAM30m (see Figure 2), and the Component~A contribution is estimated to be 3.3 Jy km/s ($=$40 \%).
The SMA map has a beam of 0.79"x0.7", and the source is barely resolved. Therefore, we derived the line flux per ALMA beam by scaling with the ratio of the ALMA and SMA beam sizes, (0.2"x0.2")/(0.79"x0.7").
The integrated CO lines are broad (~700-1100 km/s FWHM; Figure 2), but the velocity width within an ALMA beam without a system-wide gradient is likely ~100 km/s. Therefore, we divide the ALMA-beam line flux by this velocity width. The resultant peak flux density per ALMA beam is 15 mJy.
Since the line is bright, we aim to achieve a high signal-to-noise ratio of 15. The requested sensitivity is therefore 1 mJy. The required observing time is 0.54 hours.
The continuum brightness of Component A is 20 mJy at 880 um. By assuming a continuum slope of beta =-1.5 and scaling with the ratio of the ALMA and SMA beam sizes (0.2"x0.2")/(0.79"x0.7"), the expected continuum flux per ALMA beam is 0.2 mJy. Since the expected continuum sensitivity is 0.03 mJy according to the ALMA OT, the continuum will be detectd with a signal-to-noise ratio of 6 per ALMA beam.

----------------- Correlator setup -----------------
For a good sampling of the line profile, we will use the correlator mode with dual polarization, 1.875 GHz bandwidth, and 1.938 MHz (6 km/s) resolution, and will average to 20 km/s channels.
The integrated CO lines are broad (~700-1100 km/s FWHM; Figure 2), but the velocity width within an ALMA beam without a system-wide gradient is likely ~100 km/s. The 20km/s channels will allow us to critically sample the line profile with 5 spectral resolution elements per line width.

------------------- Spatial resolution -------------------
The SMA map shows that Components A and B are compact and barely resolved with a beam of 0.79''x0.7''. To examine the spatial and velocity structures of these sources in greater detail and to better compare with the 0.2" images obtained for the Band 7 and 6 observations, we request the best Band 6 spatial resolution of 0.5". Also, none of the features we see in the SMA map is larger than 2".

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: MACS0257 [NII] 205 um/CO(12-11)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: To map the [NII] 205um line and Band 6 continuum with a 0.2" resolution as well as to attempt the detection of the high-excitation CO(12-11) line.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Note: The requested observing parameters are summarized in Table 1 in the Scientific Justification.
---------------- Target features ----------------
[NII] 205 um line and dust continuum. We will also examine the detectability of the high-excitation CO(12-11) line simultaneously.
At z=4.69, the [NII] line is redshifted into Band 6.
--------- Pointing ---------
Based on the SMA image in Figure 3, we expect to detect four lensed images. The diagonal image separation (A--D, B--C) is ~17'', which is comparable to the primary beam size in Band 6. Therefore, to avoid placing all four components near the edge of the primary beam, which would cause a significant loss of sensitivity, we will image the two brightest components A and B only by pointing ALMA to the mid-point between the two. This will produce two independent measurements of the background SMG, which will help us improve the accuracy of the lens model and assess the reality of faint features. In terms of the final sensitivity, coadding the two brightest images obtained this way (each displaced by 5'' from the field center) is comparable to observing Component A (or B) alone by placing it at the field center. Therefore, we use the latter case for the sensitivity calculation for simplicity.
------------------- Spatial resolution -------------------
The SMA map shows that Components A and B are compact and barely resolved with a beam of 0.79''x0.7''. To examine the spatial and velocity structures of these sources in greater detail, we request a spatial resolution of 0.2". Since the [CII]/[NII] ratio will be used to map the gas metallicity distribution, we would like to use the same spatial resolution for the Band 6 and Band 7 observations.
----------------- Correlator setup -----------------
For a good sampling of the line profile, we will use the correlator mode with dual polarization, 1.875 GHz bandwidth, and 3.904 MHz (5 km/s) resolution, and will average to 20 km/s channels.
------------ Sensitivity ------------
The total [NII] line flux (2.1 Jy km/s) for Component A was estimated by assuming a [NII]/[CII] line ratio of 0.052 (Rawle et al. 2014).
The SMA map has a beam of 0.79"x0.7", and the source is barely resolved. Therefore, we derived the line flux per ALMA beam by scaling with the ratio of the ALMA and SMA beam sizes, (0.2"x0.2")/(0.79"x0.7").
The integrated CO lines are broad (~700-1100 km/s FWHM; Figure 2), but the velocity width within an ALMA beam without a system-wide gradient is likely ~100 km/s. Therefore, we divide the ALMA-beam line flux by this velocity width. The resultant peak flux density per ALMA beam is 1.5 mJy.
Since the line is faint, we aim to achieve a minimum acceptable signal-to-noise ratio of 5. The requested sensitivity is therefore 0.5 mJy. The required observing time is 0.93 hours. If necessary, we will smooth the data to bring up the [NII] signal.
The continuum brightness of Component A is 20 mJy at 880 um. By scaling with the ratio of the ALMA and SMA beam sizes (0.2"x0.2")/(0.79"x0.7"), the expected continuum flux per ALMA beam is 1.4 mJy. Therefore, we roughly estimate the Band 6 continuum to be 0.9 mJy. Since the expected continuum sensitivity is 0.02 mJy according to the ALMA OT, the continuum will be detected with a signal to noise of 40 per ALMA beam, which should be high enough to resolve star-forming clumps in the source.

----------------- Correlator setup -----------------
For a good sampling of the line profile, we will use the correlator mode with dual polarization, 1.875 GHz bandwidth, and 3.904 MHz (5 km/s) resolution, and will average to 20 km/s channels.
The integrated CO lines are broad (~700-1100 km/s FWHM; Figure 2), but the velocity width within an ALMA beam without a system-wide gradient is likely ~100 km/s. The 20km/s channels will allow us to critically sample the line profile with 5 spectral resolution elements per line width.

------------------- Spatial resolution -------------------
The SMA map shows that Components A and B are compact and barely resolved with a beam of 0.79''x0.7''. To examine the spatial and velocity structures of these sources in greater detail, we request a spatial resolution of 0.2". Also, none of the features we see in the SMA map is larger than 2".

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: MACS2043 CO(7-6)/CI(2-1)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Simultaneous mapping of CO(7-6), CI(2-1), and H20(2,1,1-2,0,2) lines as well as dust continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Note: The requested observing parameters are summarized in Table 1 in the Scientific Justification.
---------------- Target features ----------------
CO(7-6)) line and dust continuum. CI(2-1) and H2O(2,1,1-2,0,2) lines will also be observed simultaneously.
At z=2.04, the CO(7-6) line is redshifted into Band 6.
--------- Pointing ---------
We will point to the gravitational arc detected strongly in the SMA map (Figure 1).
------------------- Spatial resolution -------------------
To resolve individual star-forming regions in this gravitational arc, we request a spatial resolution of 0.2".
----------------- Correlator setup -----------------
For a good sampling of the line profile, we will use the correlator mode with dual polarization, 1.875 GHz bandwidth, and 3.904 MHz (5 km/s) resolution, and will average to 20 km/s channels.
------------ Sensitivity ------------
Using the Eyelash galaxy as a guide and scaling to the infrared luminosity of this source, we estimate a CO(7-6) line flux of 9.1 Jy km/s.
The arc is very thin, and the JVLA data shows that the CO(1-0) emission is extending over 5" along the arc. We therefore calculate the line flux per ALMA beam by taking the ratio of the ALMA beam size and the length of the CO emitting arc (0.2"/5").
The velocity width within an ALMA beam without a system-wide gradient is likely ~100 km/s. Therefore, we divide the ALMA-beam line flux by this velocity width. The resultant peak flux density per ALMA beam is 4 mJy.
Since the JVLA CO(1-0) line intensity varies significantly along the arc, we aim to achieve a good signal-to-noise ratio of 10 on average. The requested sensitivity is therefore 0.4 mJy. The required observing time is 1.3 hours.
The continuum brightness of the arc is 50 mJy at 870 um from the SMA observation. Scaling with the ratio of the ALMA beam size to the length of the continuum-emitting arc (0.2"/5"), we estimate the continuum brightness per ALMA beam to be 2 mJy. Since the expected continuum sensitivity is 0.02 mJy according to the ALMA OT, the continuum will be detected with a signal to noise of 100 per ALMA beam, which will resolve star-forming clumps in the source in great detail. Since the continuum intensity varies significantly along the arc, such a good sensitivity will allow us to examine faint features.

----------------- Correlator setup -----------------
For a good sampling of the line profile, we will use the correlator mode with dual polarization, 1.875 GHz bandwidth, and 3.904 MHz (5 km/s) resolution, and will average to 20 km/s channels.
The velocity width within an ALMA beam without a system-wide gradient is likely ~100 km/s. The 20km/s channels will allow us to critically sample the line profile with 5 spectral resolution elements per line width.

------------------- Spatial resolution -------------------
To resolve individual star-forming regions in this gravitational arc, we request a spatial resolution of 0.2". The SMA, JVLA, and VLT images shown in Figure 1 have a spatial resolution of ~1", and these images clearly indicate that higher-resolution ALMA maps will help us resolve and study this spectacular lensed SMG in greater detail.
The gravitational arc is extended over 5", but what we would like to do is to resolve the clumpy structures inside the arc. Therefore, we set the largest angular scale to be 2".

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
In the course of our Herschel Lensing Survey (HLS) (PI: Egami), we have discovered two exceptionally bright cluster-lensed submillimeter galaxy (SMG) at z=2.04 and 4.69. Their exceptional brightnesses (50-60 mJy at 870 um) and large magnification factors (x30 and x130) make them excellent ALMA targets for detailed studies. Our goal is to resolve these galaxies into individual star-forming regions with a spatial resolution of ~100 pc, comparable to the size of local giant molecular clouds (GMC). Scientifically, the first question we will ask is, "Are GMCs in high-redshift SMGs super-sized versions of local GMC dense cores as shown by Swinbank et al. (2010) for the Eyelash galaxy?" By measuring the sizes and brightnesses of detected continuum sources and correcting for lensing magnification, we will address this question directly. We will also probe the internal structures of various gas components, and will examine how the different phases of the ISM relate to each other (and to continuum), tyring to better understand the properties and origin of these galaxies.
This is a Cycle 2 Priority B program with a time allocation of 3.5 hours, but no data have been obtained so far.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
